trans-unit.source: Named Entity Recognition
trans-unit.target: Named Entity Recognition

trans-unit.source: Recognizes named entities in a text column
trans-unit.target: Recognizes named entities in a text column

trans-unit.source: Category: <link xlink:href="c790e4eb-2aae-4228-a12f-69809b9e70ae" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Text Analytics</link>
trans-unit.target: Category: <link xlink:href="c790e4eb-2aae-4228-a12f-69809b9e70ae" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Text Analytics</link>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module to identify the names of things, such as people, companies, or locations in a column of text.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module to identify the names of things, such as people, companies, or locations in a column of text.

trans-unit.source: The module then labels the sequences where these words were found so that you can use the terms in further analysis.
trans-unit.target: The module then labels the sequences where these words were found so that you can use the terms in further analysis.

trans-unit.source: Named entity recognition is an important area of research in machine learning and natural language processing (NLP), because it can be used to answer many real-world questions, such as:
trans-unit.target: Named entity recognition is an important area of research in machine learning and natural language processing (NLP), because it can be used to answer many real-world questions, such as:

trans-unit.source: Does a tweet contain the name of a person?
trans-unit.target: Does a tweet contain the name of a person?

trans-unit.source: Does the tweet also provide his current location?
trans-unit.target: Does the tweet also provide his current location?

trans-unit.source: Which companies were mentioned in a news article?
trans-unit.target: Which companies were mentioned in a news article?

trans-unit.source: Were specified products mentioned in complaints?
trans-unit.target: Were specified products mentioned in complaints?

trans-unit.source: To get a list of named entities, you provide a dataset as input that contains a text column.
trans-unit.target: To get a list of named entities, you provide a dataset as input that contains a text column.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module will then identify three types of entities: people (PER), locations (LOC), and organizations (ORG).
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module will then identify three types of entities: people (PER), locations (LOC), and organizations (ORG).

trans-unit.source: For example, the following table shows a simple input sentence, and the terms and values generated by the module:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following table shows a simple input sentence, and the terms and values generated by the module:

trans-unit.source: Input text
trans-unit.target: Input text

trans-unit.source: Module output
trans-unit.target: Module output

trans-unit.source: “Boston is a great place to live.”
trans-unit.target: “Boston is a great place to live.”

trans-unit.source: 0,Boston,0,6,LOC
trans-unit.target: 0,Boston,0,6,LOC

trans-unit.source: The output can be interpreted as follows:
trans-unit.target: The output can be interpreted as follows:

trans-unit.source: The first ‘0’ means that this string is the first article input to the module.
trans-unit.target: The first ‘0’ means that this string is the first article input to the module.

trans-unit.source: Because a single article can have multiple entities, including the article row number in the output is important for mapping features to articles.
trans-unit.target: Because a single article can have multiple entities, including the article row number in the output is important for mapping features to articles.

trans-unit.source: ‘Boston’ is the recognized entity.
trans-unit.target: ‘Boston’ is the recognized entity.

trans-unit.source: The ‘0’ that follows ‘Boston’ means the entity ‘Boston’ starts from the first letter of the input string.
trans-unit.target: The ‘0’ that follows ‘Boston’ means the entity ‘Boston’ starts from the first letter of the input string.

trans-unit.source: (Indices are zero-based.)
trans-unit.target: (Indices are zero-based.)

trans-unit.source: ‘6’ means the length of ‘Boston’ is 6.
trans-unit.target: ‘6’ means the length of ‘Boston’ is 6.

trans-unit.source: ‘LOC’ means the recognized ‘Boston’ is a location.
trans-unit.target: ‘LOC’ means the recognized ‘Boston’ is a location.

trans-unit.source: Other supported named entity types are person (PER) and organization (ORG).
trans-unit.target: Other supported named entity types are person (PER) and organization (ORG).

trans-unit.source: How to Use Named Entity Recognition
trans-unit.target: How to Use Named Entity Recognition

trans-unit.source: Add the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module to your experiment
trans-unit.target: Add the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module to your experiment

trans-unit.source: Connect these required and optional inputs:
trans-unit.target: Connect these required and optional inputs:

trans-unit.source: <ui>Story</ui>.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Story</ui>.

trans-unit.source: A source of text that contains the named entities you want to extract.
trans-unit.target: A source of text that contains the named entities you want to extract.

trans-unit.source: (required)
trans-unit.target: (required)

trans-unit.source: You can use any dataset that contains a text column.
trans-unit.target: You can use any dataset that contains a text column.

trans-unit.source: However, if the input dataset contains multiple columns, use <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" DisplayType="title" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> to choose the column that contains the text you want to analyze.
trans-unit.target: However, if the input dataset contains multiple columns, use <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" DisplayType="title" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> to choose the column that contains the text you want to analyze.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Custom Resources (Zip)</ui>.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Custom Resources (Zip)</ui>.

trans-unit.source: An optional set of linguistic resources in ZIP format.
trans-unit.target: An optional set of linguistic resources in ZIP format.

trans-unit.source: (optional)
trans-unit.target: (optional)

trans-unit.source: Currently this input is disabled.
trans-unit.target: Currently this input is disabled.

trans-unit.source: In future versions of this module, the right-hand input port will accept custom resource files, for identifying different entity-types.
trans-unit.target: In future versions of this module, the right-hand input port will accept custom resource files, for identifying different entity-types.

trans-unit.source: Run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: The module outputs a dataset containing entities, offsets, and article IDs, as described above.
trans-unit.target: The module outputs a dataset containing entities, offsets, and article IDs, as described above.

trans-unit.source: You can convert this to CSV for download or save it as a dataset for re-use.
trans-unit.target: You can convert this to CSV for download or save it as a dataset for re-use.

trans-unit.source: Using Named Entity Recognition in a Web Service
trans-unit.target: Using Named Entity Recognition in a Web Service

trans-unit.source: If you publish a web service from Azure Machine Learning Studio and want to consume the web service by using C#, Python, or another language such as R, you must first implement the service code provided on the help page of the web service.
trans-unit.target: If you publish a web service from Azure Machine Learning Studio and want to consume the web service by using C#, Python, or another language such as R, you must first implement the service code provided on the help page of the web service.

trans-unit.source: If your web service provides multiple rows of output, the URL of the web service that you add to your C#, Python, or R code should have the suffix <codeInline>scoremultirow</codeInline> instead of <codeInline>score</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: If your web service provides multiple rows of output, the URL of the web service that you add to your C#, Python, or R code should have the suffix <codeInline>scoremultirow</codeInline> instead of <codeInline>score</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: For example, assume you use the following URL for your web service:
trans-unit.target: For example, assume you use the following URL for your web service:

trans-unit.source: To enable multi-row output, change the URL to:
trans-unit.target: To enable multi-row output, change the URL to:

trans-unit.source: To publish this web service, you should add an additional <link xlink:href="30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Execute R Script</link> module after the <token>M_Ner</token> module, to transform the multi-row output into a single delimited with semi-colons (;).
trans-unit.target: To publish this web service, you should add an additional <link xlink:href="30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Execute R Script</link> module after the <token>M_Ner</token> module, to transform the multi-row output into a single delimited with semi-colons (;).

trans-unit.source: The reason for consolidating the multiple rows of output into a single row is to return multiple entities per input row.
trans-unit.target: The reason for consolidating the multiple rows of output into a single row is to return multiple entities per input row.

trans-unit.source: For example, let’s assume you have an input sentence with two named entities.
trans-unit.target: For example, let’s assume you have an input sentence with two named entities.

trans-unit.source: Rather than returning two rows for each row of input, you can return a single rows with multiple entities, separated by semi-colons as shown here:
trans-unit.target: Rather than returning two rows for each row of input, you can return a single rows with multiple entities, separated by semi-colons as shown here:

trans-unit.source: Input Text
trans-unit.target: Input Text

trans-unit.source: Output of Web Service
trans-unit.target: Output of Web Service

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has two office locations in Boston.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft has two office locations in Boston.

trans-unit.source: 0,Microsoft,0,9,ORG,;,0,Boston,38,6,LOC,;
trans-unit.target: 0,Microsoft,0,9,ORG,;,0,Boston,38,6,LOC,;

trans-unit.source: Language Support
trans-unit.target: Language Support

trans-unit.source: Currently, the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module supports only English text.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the <ui>Named Entity Recognition</ui> module supports only English text.

trans-unit.source: It can detect organization names, personal names, and locations in English sentences.
trans-unit.target: It can detect organization names, personal names, and locations in English sentences.

trans-unit.source: If you use the module on other languages, you might not get an error, but the results will not be as good as for English text.
trans-unit.target: If you use the module on other languages, you might not get an error, but the results will not be as good as for English text.

trans-unit.source: In future, support for additional languages can be enabled by integrating the multilingual components provided in the Office Natural Language Toolkit.
trans-unit.target: In future, support for additional languages can be enabled by integrating the multilingual components provided in the Office Natural Language Toolkit.

trans-unit.source: Custom Resources
trans-unit.target: Custom Resources

trans-unit.source: In future versions of this module, the right-hand input port will accept custom resource files, for identifying different entity-types.
trans-unit.target: In future versions of this module, the right-hand input port will accept custom resource files, for identifying different entity-types.

trans-unit.source: This section will describe the formats and requirements of those resources.
trans-unit.target: This section will describe the formats and requirements of those resources.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: There are no examples that use this particular module at this time.
trans-unit.target: There are no examples that use this particular module at this time.

trans-unit.source: Please check back later.
trans-unit.target: Please check back later.

trans-unit.source: However, the following sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink> demonstrate other text classification methods commonly used in machine learning:
trans-unit.target: However, the following sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink> demonstrate other text classification methods commonly used in machine learning:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>News Categorization sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525167</linkUri></externalLink> uses feature hashing to classify articles into a predefined list of categories.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>News Categorization sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525167</linkUri></externalLink> uses feature hashing to classify articles into a predefined list of categories.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Similar Companies sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525164</linkUri></externalLink> uses the text of Wikipedia articles to categorize companies.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Similar Companies sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525164</linkUri></externalLink> uses the text of Wikipedia articles to categorize companies.

trans-unit.source: In the five-part <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification sample</linkText><linkUri>Text Classification sample</linkUri></externalLink>, text from Twitter messages is used to perform sentiment analysis.
trans-unit.target: In the five-part <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification sample</linkText><linkUri>Text Classification sample</linkUri></externalLink>, text from Twitter messages is used to perform sentiment analysis.

trans-unit.source: A variety of text pre-processing techniques are also demonstrated.
trans-unit.target: A variety of text pre-processing techniques are also demonstrated.
